headline: QUIZ: Historic women you should know
description: Given a photo of a woman who made history, can you pick that person's actual name?
question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Journalist Nellie Bly pioneered under-cover investigative journalism and also traveled around the freaking world in 72 days. This was in 1889.
result: 0-8 The bright side here is you have a lot you can learn.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Sandra Day O'Connor was the first woman to serve on the U.S. Supreme Court.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Brooklynite Shirley Chisholm was the first African American woman in Congress (1968) and the first black woman to seek the nomination for president from one of the two major political parties (1972).
result: 13-15 I've written a lot of these answer results and I've never been more impressed with anyone than I am with the people who got this many right on this quiz.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Marie researched radioactivity and was the queen of science firsts. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, the first person and only woman to win twice, the only person to win a Nobel Prize in two different sciences. She was also the first woman to become a professor at the University of Paris and, in 1995, she became the first woman to be entombed on her own merits in the Panthéon in Paris.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Before Venus and Serena, Billie Jean King was a female tennis big shot. She broke down barriers by pushing for equal prize money for women and becoming one of the first well-known openly gay athletes.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Indira Gandhi was the first and so far the only female Prime Minister of India. Despite her last name, she is not related to the family of Indian activist Mahatma Gandhi.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: The first #BlackLivesMatter activist, Ida B. Wells, was a journalist, abolitionist and feminist. After the killing of three black men in Memphis, she led an anti-lynching crusade in the United States in the 1890s and became one of the founding members of the NAACP.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: The first female publisher of a major American newspaper, Katharine Graham guided the Washington Post through publishing the Pentagon Papers and the details of the Watergate scandal. Oh, and she was also first female Fortune 500 CEO. #bossbabe

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: After answering a newspaper ad for astronauts, physicist Sally Ride became the first American woman in space aboard the space shuttle Challenger in 1983.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Selfie pioneer Frida Kahlo made bold unibrows and mustaches on women look effortlessly beautiful. Her paintings didn't get much love in her day but today the Mexican artist's iconic images have a cultish following.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Dorothy Hodgkin worked in the field of three-dimensional biomolecular structures, X-ray crystallography and the structure of proteins. In other words, she discovered what insulin, vitamin B12 and penicillin look like at the microscopic level. Boom.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Before Rosa Parks, there was Claudette Colvin. When she was 15 years old, Colvin refused to give up her seat on a bus months before Parks' more-famous protest (and two years after Baton Rouge's historic 1953 bus boycott).

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Toni Morrison is a Nobel- and Pulitzer Prize-winning American author, editor and professor known for the way she writes about the black female experience. Her best known novels include "The Bluest Eye," "Song of Solomon" and "Beloved."

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Women's rights activist and New Yorker Margaret Sanger brought the term "birth control" to the public, opened the first birth control clinic in the United States (which she was arrested for), and founded the organization that would go on to be Planned Parenthood.

question: Which historic woman is this?
blurb: Eccentric, American poet Emily Dickinson challenged poetic form and structure with her verse. Most of her thousand-plus poems were published after she died.
